States that had passed photo identification requirements but had not received federal preclearance were allowed to have those laws immediately take effect.{{cite web|title=Texas Voter ID Law "Will Take..."|url=http://trailblazersblog.dallasnews.com/2013/06/texas-voter-id-law-could-start-now-attorney-general-greg-abbott.html/ |publisher=''Dallas News''|accessdate=June 26, 2013}} ===Court challenges=== The practical effect of striking out section 4(b) of the ''Voting Rights Act'' in ''Shelby'''s case was that a challenge to electoral law changes in covered states could no longer be determined by a federal administrative or judicial officer, instead having to be litigated in a court of law on a case-by-case basis, a much more costly and time-consuming process. By the end of August 2017, federal courts had struck down voter ID laws in [[Ohio]], [[Texas]], [[North Carolina]] and [[Wisconsin]]. All the cases are likely to be heard ultimately by the US Supreme Court. The court ruled that the legislature's ending of Ohio's "Golden Week" imposed a "modest burden" on the right to vote of African Americans and said that the state's justifications for the law "fail to outweigh that burden." This week had been a period of time when residents could "register to vote and cast an early ballot at the same location." The Texas law was struck down because it was found to discriminate against black and Hispanic voters.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/10/us/federal-judge-strikes-down-texas-voter-id-law.html|title=Federal Judge Says Texas Voter ID Law Intentionally Discriminates|publisher=|accessdate=August 14, 2018}} A North Carolina law was overturned as "its provisions deliberately target African-Americans with almost surgical precision … in an effort to depress black turnout at the polls." North Carolina appealed to the US Supreme Court, which declined to hear the appeal, allowing the prior federal court decision to stand.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/05/15/us/politics/voter-id-laws-supreme-court-north-carolina.html|title=Strict North Carolina Voter ID Law Thwarted After Supreme Court Rejects Case|publisher=|accessdate=August 14, 2018}} Parts of Wisconsin's voter ID laws were ruled to be unconstitutional and it was advised to accept more forms of identification for the fall 2016 election cycle. == History == Voter ID laws go back to 1950, when South Carolina became the first state to start requesting identification from voters at the polls. The identification document did not have to include a picture; any document with the name of the voter sufficed. In 1970, Hawaii joined in requiring ID, and Texas a year later. Florida was next in 1977, and Alaska in 1980 to become the first five states in the United States to request identification of some sort from voters at the polls.{{cite web|url=http://www.ncsl.org/research/elections-and-campaigns/voter-id-history.aspx#History|title=Voter ID History|work=ncsl.org|accessdate=November 5, 2014}} In 1999, Virginia Governor [[Jim Gilmore]] attempted to start a pilot program that required voters to show IDs at the polls. His initiative was blocked by Democrats and the NAACP, and was stopped by court order. His administration had spent and mailed $275,000 worth of free voter ID cards to residents in Arlington and Fairfax counties.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/local/daily/oct99/voting23.htm |title=Va. High Court Panel Bars Voter ID Plan |work=The Washington Post |date=October 23, 1999 |accessdate=November 12, 2011}}{{cite news|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/dailypress/access/82332020.html?dids=82332020:82332020&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Oct+02%2C+1999&author=The+Associated+Press&pub=Daily+Press&desc=VOTERS+IN+10+LOCALITIES+TO+RECEIVE+ID+CARDS&pqatl=google |title=Voters in 10 Localities to Receive ID Cards |publisher=Pqasb.pqarchiver.com |date=October 2, 1999 |accessdate=November 12, 2011}} Afterward Republican-dominated states have worked to pass laws for voter IDs, ostensibly to prevent "voter fraud", which studies have shown is "vanishingly rare." Opponents say that many of the provisions of such laws are a conspiracy designed to disadvantage minorities, poor and elderly, many of whom have tended in recent years to vote Democratic, so the Republicans are deriving political benefits from their voter ID campaign. In 2002, President Bush signed the [[Help America Vote Act]] into law, which required all first-time voters in federal elections to show photo or non-photo ID upon either registration or arrival at the polling place.{{cite web |author=Daphne Eviatar |url=http://washingtonindependent.com/9136/democrats-gop-challenge-voter-laws |title=Florida 2000 Redux? |publisher=The Washington Independent |date=October 1, 2008 |accessdate=November 12, 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110808054656/http://washingtonindependent.com/9136/democrats-gop-challenge-voter-laws# |archive-date=August 8, 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }} In 2004, Arizona [[Arizona Proposition 200 (2004)|passed a law]] requiring voters to bring a state-issued photo ID to the polling place. Similar proposals were discussed in various other states and were passed in some cases. In several states, a person's citizenship status is noted on their photo ID.{{cite news|last=Urbina |first=Ian |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/05/12/us/politics/12vote.html?pagewanted=1 |title=Voter ID Battle Shifts to Proof of Citizenship |location=Missouri;Florida;Kansas;Oklahoma;South Carolina;Arizona;Indiana |work=The New York Times |date=May 12, 2008 |accessdate=November 12, 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://tucsoncitizen.com/morgue/2008/01/16/74246-more-states-may-copy-arizona-s-proof-of-citizenship-voter-requirement/ |title=More states may copy Arizona's proof-of-citizenship voter requirement |work=Tucson Citizen |date=January 16, 2008 |accessdate=November 12, 2011}} Indiana passed a law in 2005 requiring a photo ID be shown by all voters before casting ballots.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/04/28/AR2008042800968.html |title=High Court Upholds Indiana Law On Voter ID |work=The Washington Post |accessdate=November 12, 2011 |first=Robert |last=Barnes |date=April 29, 2008}} Civil rights groups in Indiana launched a lawsuit, [[Crawford v. Marion County Election Board]], that reached the Supreme Court in 2008. The Court ruled that the law was constitutional, paving the way for expanded ID laws in other states.{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=17970225 |title=Supreme Court Hears Indiana Voter ID Case |publisher=NPR |accessdate=November 12, 2011}}{{cite news|last=Biskupic |first=Joan |url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/washington/2008-01-06-court_N.htm |title=Voter ID case could affect election laws |work=USA Today |date=January 6, 2008 |accessdate=November 12, 2011}} In 2011, Wisconsin Governor [[Scott Walker (politician)|Scott Walker]] ([[2011 Wisconsin Act 23|WI Act 23]]) and Ohio Governor [[John Kasich]] enacted similar laws. Texas Governor [[Rick Perry]] placed a voter ID bill as an "emergency item" in 2011, allowing legislators to rush it through the process.{{cite web|url=http://www.texasobserver.org/component/k2/item/17879-voter-id-signed-into-law |title=After Six-Year Fight, Perry Signs Voter ID into Law|publisher=Texasobserver.org|date=May 27, 2011|accessdate=November 12, 2011}} Jurisdiction over Texas election procedure had been given to the Department of Justice, which was required to [[Voting Rights Act#Section 5 - Preclearance|pre-clear]] the law for approval. The Texas law recognized government-issued photo identification and weapons permits but not college IDs, resulting in criticism that the law was unfavorable to young voters, who trend liberal, while favorable to gun owners, who trend conservative.{{cite news|url=http://www.economist.com/node/21529061 |title=Voter identification: First, show your face|work=The Economist|date=September 17, 2011|accessdate=November 12, 2011}} Rhode Island passed a voter ID law in 2011; it is the only state with a Democratic-controlled legislature to do so.{{cite web|url=http://www.projo.com/news/politics/content/POLITICAL_SCENE_12_09-12-11_79Q8DCC_v60.734a3.html |title=''Providence Journal'' article|website=Projo.com|date=August 23, 2011|accessdate=November 12, 2011}}{{dead link|date=May 2016}} In South Carolina, Gov. [[Nikki Haley]] enacted a 2011 law requiring government-issued IDs at the polls, which included provisions for the issuance of free IDs. Haley made a one-time offer to arrange for voter ID applicants to be driven to issuing locations.{{cite web |last=Smith |first=Gina |url=http://www.thestate.com/2011/09/01/1954382/free-rides-to-dmv-offered-for.html |title=Free rides to DMV offered for photo IDs – Local / Metro |publisher=TheState.com |accessdate=November 12, 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120124163738/http://www.thestate.com/2011/09/01/1954382/free-rides-to-dmv-offered-for.html |archive-date=January 24, 2012 |dead-url=yes }} The ID requirement was blocked by the Justice Department.{{cite news|author=Meg Kinnard |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/12/23/south-carolina-voter-id-law_n_1168162.html |title=HuffPost, 23 December 2011: South Carolina Voter ID Law: Justice Department Blocks Controversial Legislation |publisher=Huffingtonpost.com |date= December 23, 2011|accessdate=October 2, 2012}} [[2011 Wisconsin Act 23|Wisconsin's Voter ID law]] in 2011 provided free IDs to people who did not have them. But in practice, state employees at the DMV were instructed to provide the IDs for free only if people specifically asked to have their fee waived.{{citation needed|date=October 2014}} The requirement to show photo ID had been declared in violation of the [[Wisconsin Constitution]] and blocked by state and federal judges, but those decisions were overturned by the [[Wisconsin Supreme Court]] and later the [[7th Circuit Court of Appeals]].{{citation needed|date=October 2014}} Weeks later, the U.S. Supreme Court again blocked the law for 2014.{{citation needed|date=October 2014}} On March 23, 2015, the U.S. Supreme Court rejected an appeal by the [[ACLU]], effectively upholding the 7th Circuit's decision Wisconsin's voter ID law as constitutional.Hurley, Lawrence (March 23, 2015) – [https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/03/23/us-usa-court-election-idUSKBN0MJ1DZ20150323 "U.S. top court rejects challenge to Wisconsin voter ID law"]. ''Reuters''. Retrieved March 24, 2015. Pennsylvania's voter ID law allowed various forms of photo identification cards, including those held by drivers, government employees, in-state college students, and residents of elder-care facilities. Voters who do not possess these forms of identification can obtain voting-only photo IDs issued by the Pennsylvania Department of State through the [[Pennsylvania Department of Transportation]] (PennDOT).{{cite web|author=Central PA |url=http://www.pennlive.com/midstate/index.ssf/2012/03/challenges_loom_for_pennsylvan.html |title=Challenges loom for Pennsylvania's new voter ID law |publisher=PennLive.com |date= |accessdate=October 2, 2012}} A judicial order on October 2, 2012 blocked enforcement of Pennsylvania's law until after the [[United States presidential election, 2012|2012 Presidential election]]. Following a trial in the summer of 2013 and a six-month delay, Commonwealth Court Judge Bernard L. McGinley struck down Pennsylvania's voter ID law on January 17, 2014 as violative of the constitutional rights of state voters. He noted that required alternative voter IDs were available only through 71 [[Pennsylvania Department of Transportation|PennDOT]] Drivers Licensing Centers across the state. Five of the 71 DLCs are located in Philadelphia, nine counties have no DLCs at all, and DLCs have limited hours: in nine counties they are open only one day per week, and in 13 counties they are open only two days per week. The court ruled that the [[Pennsylvania Department of State]] provided too little access, no financial support to provide IDs to those without access, and no alternatives to obtaining the required IDs. Judge McGinley found that this leaves about half of Pennsylvania without DLCs for five days a week, imposing a significant barrier to obtaining Pennsylvania's "free ID".{{cite web|title=The Uncertain Future of Voter ID Laws|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/national/archive/2014/01/the-uncertain-future-of-voter-id-laws/283171/|publisher=The Atlantic|accessdate=January 18, 2014}} Photo IDs are ''not'' required to vote in PA.{{cite news|author=Karen Langley|url=http://www.post-gazette.com/stories/local/state/judge-issues-partial-injunction-on-states-voter-id-law-655822|title= Judge blocks enforcement of portion of Pa. voter ID law|publisher=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette|date=October 2, 2012 |accessdate=October 2, 2012}} Voters in Minnesota rejected a voter ID proposal on the 2012 general election ballot by a margin of 54–46%.{{cite news|last=Ragsdale |first=Jim |url=http://www.startribune.com/177667691.html |title=Voter ID drive rejected |work=Star Tribune |date=November 7, 2012 |accessdate=March 20, 2013}} It is the only such ballot defeat for a voter ID law in the country. ==''Shelby v. Holder''== On June 25, 2013, the [[US Supreme Court]] declared, by a 5–4 decision, in ''[[Shelby v. Holder]]'' that Section 4(b) of the [[Voting Rights Act of 1965]] was unconstitutional. Previously, states with a history of proven voter discrimination were required to obtain preclearance from a federal court before making changes to their voting laws."Texas Voter ID Law Struck Down: August 5, 2015." In Historic Documents of 2015, 395–404. Thousand Oaks, CA: CQ Press, 2016. {{doi| 10.4135/9781506333496.n34}}. "Section 4 of the Act contained the formula for determining which states or political subdivisions were covered by [[Section 5 of the Voting Rights Act|Section 5]]."Supreme Court Rules on Voting Rights Act: June 25, 2013." In Historic Documents of 2013, 284–98. Washington, DC: CQ Press, 2014. {{doi|10.4135/9781483347851.n31}} The majority opinion argued that the formula used to determine which jurisdictions required federal oversight or preclearance had not been updated to reflect current social conditions, including a decline in institutionalized discrimination and direct [[Voter suppression in the United States|voter suppression]]. Since the Court's decision, several states passed new voter ID laws and other restrictions on registration and on voting. == Studies and analysis== A 2005 report by [[Jimmy Carter|former President Jimmy Carter]] and [[James A. Baker|Former Secretary of State James Baker]] concluded that concerns of both those who support and oppose strengthened voter ID laws were legitimate. It recommended voter ID requirements be enacted, to be slowly phased in over a period of five years, and accompanied by the issuance of free ID cards provided by mobile ID vans that would visit traditionally underserved communities.{{cite web|url=http://www.cartercenter.org/news/editorials_speeches/voter_id.html |title=A Clearer Picture on Voter ID|last1=Carter|first1=Jimmy|last2=Baker|first2=James|date=February 3, 2008|website=cartercenter.org|publisher=Carter Center|accessdate=May 14, 2014}} In 2007, a report prepared by the staff of the federal [[Election Assistance Commission]] concluded "there is a great deal of debate on the pervasiveness of fraud."{{Citation|last=Urbina|first=Ian|title=Panel Said to Alter Finding on Voter Fraud|newspaper=The New York Times|date=April 11, 2007|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/04/11/washington/11voters.html?pagewanted=1&ei=5124&en=cba2ba0f1aeb218f&ex=1334030400&partner=permalink&exprod=permalink&adxnnlx=1324148609-vab5WlqTVNG6TQ/Xp4VjMA |accessdate=December 17, 2011}} === Cost of voter identification cards === According to a Harvard study, "the expenses for documentation, travel, and waiting time [for obtaining voter identification cards] are significant—especially for minority group and low-income voters—typically ranging from about $75 to $175. When legal fees are added to these numbers, the costs range as high as $1,500."{{Cite news|url=http://today.law.harvard.edu/free-voter-ids-costly-harvard-law-report-finds/|title='Free' voter IDs are costly, Harvard Law report finds – Harvard Law Today|newspaper=Harvard Law Today|access-date=January 11, 2017}}{{Cite web|url=http://today.law.harvard.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/FullReportVoterIDJune20141.pdf|title=The High Cost of 'Free' Photo Voter Identification Cards|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}} So even if the cards themselves may be free, the costs associated with obtaining the card can be expensive. The author of the study notes that the costs associated with obtaining the card far exceeds the $1.50 poll tax outlawed by the 24th amendment in 1964. ===Fraud prevention=== The vast majority of voter ID laws in the United States target only [[voter impersonation]], of which there are only 31 documented cases in the United States from the 2000–2014 period.{{cite web | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2014/10/13/the-disconnect-between-voter-id-laws-and-voter-fraud/ | title=The disconnect between voter ID laws and voter fraud | publisher=The Washington Post | work=The Fix | date=October 13, 2014 | accessdate=July 26, 2016 | author=Bump, Philip}} According to ''[[PolitiFact.com|PolitiFact]]'', "in-person voter fraud—the kind targeted by the ID law—remains extremely rare".{{Cite web|url=http://www.politifact.com/texas/statements/2016/mar/17/greg-abbott/light-match-greg-abbotts-claim-about-rampant-voter/|title=None|access-date=August 3, 2016}} According to the ''[[Associated Press]]'', the ''[[The New York Times|New York Times]],'' [[NPR]], [[CNBC]], ''[[the Guardian]]'' and [[FactCheck.org|FactCheck.Org]] the available research and evidence point to the type of fraud that would be prevented by voter ID laws as "very rare" or "extremely rare".{{Cite news|url=https://www.apnews.com/dafac088c90242ef8b282fbebddf5b56|title=In Wisconsin, ID law proved insurmountable for many voters|work=AP News|access-date=May 14, 2017|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/24/us/supreme-court-rejects-challenge-to-wisconsin-voter-id-law.html|title=Wisconsin Decides Not to Enforce Voter ID Law|last=Liptak|first=Adam|date=March 23, 2015|work=The New York Times|access-date=May 14, 2017|issn=0362-4331}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2016/09/07/493001761/despite-court-ruling-voting-rights-fight-continues-in-north-carolina|title=Despite Court Ruling, Voting Rights Fight Continues In North Carolina|website=NPR.org|access-date=May 14, 2017}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.factcheck.org/2016/10/trumps-bogus-voter-fraud-claims/|title=Trump's Bogus Voter Fraud Claims - FactCheck.org|date=October 19, 2016|work=FactCheck.org|access-date=May 14, 2017|language=en-US}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2017/05/11/trump-to-establish-vote-fraud-commission.html|title=Trump establishes vote fraud commission|last=O'Donnell|first=Ali Vitali, Peter Alexander and Kelly|date=May 11, 2017|website=CNBC|access-date=May 14, 2017}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.usnews.com/news/politics/articles/2016-10-17/trump-wrongly-insists-voter-fraud-is-very-very-common|title=trump-wrongly-insists-voter-fraud-is-very-very-common|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161020072314/http://www.usnews.com/news/politics/articles/2016-10-17/trump-wrongly-insists-voter-fraud-is-very-very-common|archive-date=October 20, 2016|dead-url=yes|access-date=}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/feb/11/texas-voter-fraud-mexican-national|title=Trump voter fraud claim was '800lb gorilla in jury box' at Texas trial|last=Press|first=Associated|date=February 11, 2017|work=The Guardian|access-date=May 14, 2017|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}} PolitiFact finds the suggestion that "voter fraud is rampant" false, giving it its "Pants on Fire" rating. Most cases of alleged voter fraud involving dead voters have been shown to be a result of incorrect matching of voter rolls and death records, such as when someone died after they voted rather than before.{{cite web | url=https://www.rollingstone.com/politics/pictures/the-voter-fraud-myth-debunked-20120612/dead-voters-0459793 | title=The 'Voter Fraud' Myth Debunked | work=Rolling Stone | date=June 12, 2012 | accessdate=August 8, 2016}} Writing in 2009, Harvard political scientist [[Stephen Ansolabehere]] noted that despite the common belief "that fraud occurs at least somewhat often in elections … social scientists have been unable to develop unambiguous measures of the incidence of fraud, and legal cases find very little hard evidence on the matter." In a 2012 analysis, [[News21]] of the [[Walter Cronkite School of Journalism and Mass Communication|Walter Cronkite School of Journalism]] surveyed thousands of election officials in 50 states regarding all instances of fraud relating to elections since 2000, and concluded that in-person voter impersonation is virtually non-existent, amounting to one out of about every 15 million prospective voters.{{cite web|url=https://votingrights.news21.com/article/election-fraud/|title=Who Can Vote? - A News21 2012 National Project|website=votingrights.news21.com|accessdate=August 14, 2018}} Proponents of voter ID laws cite the registration of dead and out-of-state voters as a vulnerability in the electoral system. A 2012 report by the [[Pew Center]] showed that more than 1.8 million deceased people remain registered to vote nationwide. The same report found 3 million voters registered in multiple states, presumably due to changes of residency.{{cite news|title=Study: 1.8 Million Dead People Still Registered to Vote|author=Pam Fessler|url=https://www.npr.org/2012/02/14/146827471/study-1-8-million-dead-people-still-registered-to-vote |work=NPR|date=February 14, 2012|accessdate=January 18, 2016}} David Becker, the director of Election Initiatives for Pew, said this study's results pointed to the need to improve voter registration, rather than to evidence of voter fraud or suppression.{{cite web|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2012/02/report-18m-dead-registered-to-vote-072830 |title=Report: 1.8M dead registered to vote|work=Politico|date=February 14, 2012|accessdate=March 28, 2016|author=Weinger, Mackenzie}} Proponents of voter ID laws fear that motivated individuals could exploit registration irregularities to impersonate dead voters or impersonate former state residents, casting multiple fraudulent ballots. Critics of such laws note that they only prevent one kind of fraud, namely voter impersonation. They say that this form of fraud is illogical, as the risks (a fine of up to $10,000 and/or 5 years in prison) far outweigh the benefits (casting one extra vote for the voter's desired candidate).{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/OTUS/voter-fraud-real-rare/story?id=17213376 |title=Voter Fraud: Non-Existent Problem or Election-Threatening Epidemic?|work=ABC News|date=September 12, 2012|accessdate=March 30, 2016|author=Bingham, Amy}} Democrats have alleged that the scale of impersonation fraud has been greatly exaggerated by Republicans for political reasons.{{cite web|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2011/09/24/voter-id-laws-target-rarely-occurring-voter-fraud.html |title=Voter ID Laws Target Rarely Occurring Voter Fraud|work=Fox News|date=September 24, 2011|accessdate=March 30, 2016|author=Associated Press}} A 2012 investigation of 207 alleged dead voters in South Carolina found only five instances unexplained by clerical errors. For instance, sometimes a son with the same name as his dead father was accidentally recorded as voting under the father's name.{{Cite news|title=The case of 'zombie' voters in South Carolina|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/fact-checker/post/the-case-of-zombie-voters-in-south-carolina/2013/07/24/86de3c64-f403-11e2-aa2e-4088616498b4_blog.html |newspaper=The Washington Post|date=July 24, 2013|accessdate=February 15, 2016|issn= 0190-8286|first=Glenn|last=Kessler}} A study of dead voters in the 2006 Georgia midterm election concluded that only fifteen of the 66 alleged instances of dead voting were potentially fraudulent. All but four of the dead votes were cast absentee, and most of the absentee voters in question cast early ballots but died before the election, giving the impression of voter fraud.{{Cite journal|title=They Just Do Not Vote Like They Used To: A Methodology to Empirically Assess Election Fraud|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1540-6237.2011.00837.x/abstract |journal=Social Science Quarterly|date=March 1, 2012|issn= 1540-6237|pages=76–94|volume= 93|issue= 1|doi= 10.1111/j.1540-6237.2011.00837.x|language=en|first=M. V.|last=Hood|first2=William|last2=Gillespie}} A 2013 study testing for additional cases of electoral fraud in addition to two cases that had already been documented found no additional cases of such fraud.{{Cite journal|title=Identifying Election Fraud Using Orphan and Low Propensity Voters|url=http://apr.sagepub.com/content/42/2/311 |journal=American Politics Research|date=March 1, 2014|issn= 1532-673X|pages=311–37|volume= 42|issue= 2|doi= 10.1177/1532673X13498411|language=en|first=Ray|last=Christensen|first2=Thomas J.|last2=Schultz}} A 2007 report by the [[Brennan Center for Justice]] concluded that voter impersonation was rarer than being struck by [[lightning]]. The author of this report, [[Justin Levitt]], later reported in 2014 that he had identified only thirty-one credible instances of voter impersonation since 2000, involving a total of 241 ballots, out of a billion ballots cast.{{cite web|url=http://america.aljazeera.com/articles/2016/2/10/republicans-champion-voter-id-laws-absent-credible-evidence-of-fraud.html |title=Republicans champion voter ID laws absent credible evidence of fraud|work=Al Jazeera America|date=February 10, 2016|accessdate=March 28, 2016|author=Diallo, Amadou}}{{cite web | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2016/08/03/heres-how-rare-in-person-voter-fraud-is/ | title=Here's how rare in-person voter fraud is | work=Washington Post | date=August 3, 2016 | accessdate=August 8, 2016 | author=Bump, Philip}} Also, in 2007, [[Lorraine Minnite]] released a report for [[Project Vote]] concluding that voter fraud was "extremely rare" in the United States.{{cite web|url=http://bradblog.com/Docs/PoliticsofVoterFraudFinal.pdf |title=The Politics of Voter Fraud|work=Project Vote|date=2007|accessdate=March 29, 2016|author=Minnite, Lorraine}} In 2014, a survey was published concluding that there was no evidence of widespread voter impersonation in the [[United States presidential election, 2012|2012 U.S. general election]].{{cite web|url=http://online.liebertpub.com/doi/abs/10.1089/elj.2013.0231 |title=liebert document|work=liebertpub.com|accessdate=May 14, 2016}} Proponents of voter ID laws have pointed to a 2014 study by [[Old Dominion University]] professors Jesse Richman and David Earnest as justification. The study, which used data developed by the Cooperative Congressional Election Study, concluded that more than 14 percent of self-identified [[non-citizens]] in 2008 and 2010 indicated that they were registered to vote, approximately 6.4% of surveyed non-citizens voted in 2008, and 2.2% of surveyed non-citizens voted in 2010.{{cite news|last=Richman|first=Jesse|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/monkey-cage/wp/2014/10/24/could-non-citizens-decide-the-november-election/ |title=Washington Post: Could non-citizens decide the November election?|work=Washington Post|date=October 24, 2014|accessdate=June 18, 2015}}{{Cite journal|title=Do non-citizens vote in U.S. elections?|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0261379414000973 |journal=[[Electoral Studies]] |date=December 1, 2014|pages=149–157|volume= 36|doi= 10.1016/j.electstud.2014.09.001|first=Jesse T.|last=Richman|first2=Gulshan A.|last2=Chattha|first3=David C.|last3=Earnest}} However, the study also concluded that voter ID requirements would be ineffective at reducing non-citizen voting.{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/business/hiltzik/la-fi-mh-steal-your-election-20141031-column.html|title=Today's voting freakout: noncitizens are coming to steal your election|date=October 31, 2014|work=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=March 28, 2016|author=Hiltzik, Michael}} This study has been criticized by numerous academics.{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/monkey-cage/wp/2014/10/27/methodological-challenges-affect-study-of-non-citizens-voting/|title=Methodological challenges affect study of non-citizens' voting|date=October 27, 2014|work=Washington Post|accessdate=February 7, 2016|author=Bump, Philip}}{{cite journal|last2=Luks|first2=Samantha|last3=Schaffner|first3=Brian F.|date=December 2015|title=The perils of cherry picking low frequency events in large sample surveys|journal=Electoral Studies|volume=40|pages=409–10|doi=10.1016/j.electstud.2015.07.002|last1=Ansolabehere|first1=Stephen}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2016/11/donald-trump-illegal-votes-evidence-debunked-214487|title=Trump's Claims About Illegal Votes Are Nonsense. I Debunked the Study He Cites as 'Evidence.'|newspaper=POLITICO Magazine|access-date=January 27, 2017}} A 2015 study by the managers of the Cooperative Congressional Election Study found that Richman and Earnest's study was "almost certainly flawed" and that, in fact, it was most likely that 0% of non-citizens had voted in recent American elections. Richman and Earnest's findings were the result of measurement error; some individuals who answered the survey checked the wrong boxes in surveys. Richman and Earnest therefore extrapolated from a handful of wrongfully classified cases to achieve an exaggerated number of individuals who appeared to be non-citizen voters. Richman later conceded that "the response error issues … may have biased our numbers".{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/26/upshot/illegal-voting-claims-and-why-they-dont-hold-up.html|title=Illegal Voting Claims, and Why They Don't Hold Up|last=Cohn|first=Nate|date=January 26, 2017|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|access-date=January 26, 2017}} Richman has also rebuked President Trump for claiming that millions voted illegally in 2016. Brian Schaffner, Professor of Political Science at University of Massachesetts, Amherst, who was part of the team that debunked Richman and Earnest's study said that the study {{Quote|text=… is not only wrong, it is irresponsible social science and should never have been published in the first place. There is no evidence that non-citizens have voted in recent U.S. elections... It is bad research, because it fails to understand basic facts about the data it uses. Indeed, it took me and my colleagues only a few hours to figure out why the authors' findings were wrong and to produce the evidence needed to prove as much. The authors were essentially basing their claims on two pieces of data associated with the large survey—a question that asks people whether they are citizens and official vote records to which each respondent has been matched to determine whether he or she had voted. Both these pieces of information include some small amounts of measurement error, as is true of all survey questions. What the authors failed to consider is that measurement error was entirely responsible for their results. In fact, once my colleagues and I accounted for that error, we found that there were essentially zero non-citizens who voted in recent elections.|author=Brian Schaffner|source=}} Support for voter ID laws correlates with perceived prevalence of voter fraud.{{Cite journal|title=The Foundations of Public Opinion on Voter ID Laws Political Predispositions, Racial Resentment, and Information Effects|url=http://poq.oxfordjournals.org/content/77/4/962 |journal=Public Opinion Quarterly|date=December 21, 2013|issn= 0033-362X|pages=962–84|volume= 77|issue= 4|doi= 10.1093/poq/nft026|language=en|first=David C.|last=Wilson|first2=Paul R.|last2=Brewer}} Although absentee ballot fraud is more common than voter impersonation, only six of the 31 states with voter ID laws also impose similar requirements on people who mail in absentee ballots.{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/frontline/article/why-voter-id-laws-arent-really-about-fraud/ |title=Why Voter ID Laws Aren't Really about Fraud|work=PBS|date=October 20, 2014|accessdate=April 14, 2016|author=Childress, Sarah}} ===Perception of electoral systems=== Lorraine Minnite of [[Demos (U.S. think tank)|Demos]] has criticized proponents of voter ID laws for shifting their arguments in favor of such laws from voter fraud to electoral integrity. In an expert report prepared for the [[ACLU]], she argued that "Calling the problem "electoral integrity" does not change the fact that the only threat to electoral integrity addressed by photo ID laws is in-person voter fraud," and that because such fraud is extremely rare, voter ID laws are not justified to prevent this problem.{{cite web | url=https://www.aclupa.org/files/1913/7960/9095/Minnite.pdf | title=Expert Report of Lorraine C. Minnite | accessdate=July 22, 2016}} But in 2005, [[American University|American University's]] Commission on Federal Election Reform, co-chaired by former President [[Jimmy Carter]] and former Secretary of State [[James Baker]], wrote: {{quote|The electoral system cannot inspire public confidence if no safeguards exist to deter or detect fraud or to confirm the identity of voters. Photo IDs currently are needed to board a plane, enter federal buildings, and cash a check. Voting is equally important.| The Commission on Federal Election Reform{{cite web|url=http://www.eac.gov/assets/1/AssetManager/Exhibit%20M.PDF |title=Building Confidence in U.S. Elections|work=American University|date=September 2005|accessdate=7 February 2016|author=The Commission on Federal Election Reform}}}} The Commission concluded that, although proven voter impersonation is minimal, a photo ID requirement will ensure election integrity and safeguard public perception of the nation's voting system at little cost to anyone. However, among certain demographics, voter ID laws lower electoral confidence. A 2016 study concluded that Democrats in states with strict ID laws have reduced faith in the electoral system. It said that negative politicization by the Democratic Party may be to blame.{{Cite journal|title=A Partisan Model of Electoral Reform Voter Identification Laws and Confidence in State Elections|url=http://spa.sagepub.com/content/early/2016/01/11/1532440015624102 |journal=State Politics & Policy Quarterly|date=January 11, 2016|issn= 1532-4400|doi= 10.1177/1532440015624102|language=en|first=Shaun|last=Bowler|first2=Todd|last2=Donovan}} On the other hand, Republicans living in strict photo identification states were more confident in their elections, though possibly due to similar politicization by Republican elites. Another 2015 study found that voters living in states with voter ID laws were not more confident in elections than voters who lived in states without such laws.{{cite journal|last1=Bowler|first1=Shaun|last2=Brunell|first2=Thomas|last3=Donovan|first3=Todd|last4=Gronke|first4=Paul|title=Election administration and perceptions of fair elections|journal=Electoral Studies|date=June 2015|volume=38|pages=1–9|doi=10.1016/j.electstud.2015.01.004}} A 2016 study found that people living in states with voter ID laws were no more confident in their elections than people in states without such laws, nor did they perceive lower rates of voter impersonation fraud.{{Cite journal |last=Stewart |first=Charles |last2=Ansolabehere |first2=Stephen |author-link2=Stephen Ansolabehere |last3=Persily |first3=Nathaniel |author-link3=Nathaniel Persily |year=2016 |title=Revisiting Public Opinion on Voter Identification and Voter Fraud in an Era of Increasing Partisan Polarization |url=https://www.stanfordlawreview.org/print/article/revisiting-public-opinion-on-voter-identification-and-voter-fraud-in-an-era-of-increasing-partisan-polarization/ |journal=[[Stanford Law Review]] |volume=68 |issue=6 |page=1455}} A 2017 study found similar results for both national and local election outcomes.{{Cite journal |last=King |first=Bridgett A. |date=June 1, 2017 |title=Policy and Precinct: Citizen Evaluations and Electoral Confidence |url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/ssqu.12303/abstract |journal=Social Science Quarterly |language=en |volume=98 |issue=2 |pages=672–689 |doi=10.1111/ssqu.12303 |issn=1540-6237}} === Turnout === Studies of the effects of voter ID laws on turnout in the United States have generally found that such laws have little, if any, effect on turnout. This may be because these laws do not reduce turnout very much; it may also be because the strictest voter ID laws have the largest effect on turnout, and they have only been enacted relatively recently.{{Cite journal |last=Highton |first=Benjamin |title=Voter Identification Laws and Turnout in the United States |url=http://annualreviews.org/doi/abs/10.1146/annurev-polisci-051215-022822 |journal=Annual Review of Political Science |volume=20}} Although most Americans possess a government-issued photo ID, those without ID may have trouble acquiring the proper credentials, lowering their turnout. The most comprehensive study of voter IDs, a 2017 study by Harvard political scientist Stephen Ansolabehere and Tufts political scientist Eitan Hersh, found that in Texas, 1.5% of those who showed up to vote in the 2012 election lacked the kinds of IDs that are targeted by voter ID laws, 4.5% of the total eligible population lacked them, 7.5% of black registered voters lack them.{{Cite news|url=https://www.wired.com/story/voter-id-law-algorithm/|title=A Dead-Simple Algorithm Reveals the True Toll of Voter ID Laws|work=WIRED|access-date=January 4, 2018|language=en-US}}{{Cite journal|last=Ansolabehere|first=Stephen|last2=Hersh|first2=Eitan D.|date=January 1, 2017|title=ADGN: An Algorithm for Record Linkage Using Address, Date of Birth, Gender, and Name|url=http://amstat.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/2330443X.2017.1389620|journal=Statistics and Public Policy|volume=4|issue=1|pages=1–10|doi=10.1080/2330443X.2017.1389620}} The numbers are likely higher in states with more urban areas, as fewer voters have driving licenses. A 2011 study by [[New York University]]'s Brennan Center estimated that of the US population that is of voting age, 6–11% lack government-issued photo ID.{{cite web|last=Weiser|first=Wendy|url=http://www.brennancenter.org/content/resource/citizens_without_proof_stands_strong/ |title=Citizens Without Proof Stands Strong|publisher=Brennan Center|date=September 8, 2011|accessdate=October 15, 2012|display-authors=etal}} [[The Heritage Foundation]], a conservative [[think tank]], disputed the methodology of the study, citing a question in which 14 percent of respondents said they had both a U.S. [[birth certificate]] and [[naturalization]] papers.{{cite web|url=http://www.bernardgoldberg.com/not-a-race-card/ |title=Not a Race Card|website=Bernardgoldberg.com|accessdate=November 12, 2011}} Since some legitimate voters lack the kind of IDs demanded by voter ID laws, some commentators have argued that strict voter ID laws reduce voter turnout, especially among poor, black, elderly, disabled, and minority-language voters, and voters who have changed their names.{{Cite journal|title=Voter-ID Laws Discourage Participation, Particularly among Minorities, and Trigger a Constitutional Remedy in Lost Representation|url=http://journals.cambridge.org/article_S1049096509090271 |journal=PS: Political Science & Politics|date=January 1, 2009|issn= 1537-5935|pages=107–10|volume= 42|issue= 01|doi= 10.1017/S1049096509090271|first=Richard|last=Sobel|first2=Robert Ellis|last2=Smith}} However, the results of studies assessing the effect (or lack thereof) of these laws on turnout have been inconclusive.{{cite journal|last1=Atkeson|first1=Lonna Rae|last2=Kerevel|first2=Yann P.|last3=Alvarez|first3=R. Michael|last4=Hall|first4=Thad E.|title=Who Asks For Voter Identification? Explaining Poll-Worker Discretion|journal=The Journal of Politics|date=October 2014|volume=76|issue=4|pages=944–57|doi=10.1017/S0022381614000528|url=http://authors.library.caltech.edu/50307/1/S0022381614000528a.pdf}}{{rp|945}} For example, a 2012 study found that a stricter voter ID law in Georgia lowered turnout by about 0.4% in 2008 compared to 2004.{{cite journal|last1=Hood|first1=M. V.|last2=Bullock|first2=C. S.|title=Much Ado About Nothing? An Empirical Assessment of the Georgia Voter Identification Statute|journal=State Politics & Policy Quarterly|date=October 15, 2012|volume= 12|issue= 4|pages=394–414|doi= 10.1177/1532440012452279}} A 2006 study also found that voter ID laws decreased aggregate turnout by between 3 and 4 percent.{{cite web | url=http://www.brennancenter.org/sites/default/files/legacy/d/download_file_50903.pdf | title=Protecting The Franchise, or Restricting It? The Effects of Voter Identification Requirements on Turnout | work=American Political Science Association Conference | date=2006 | accessdate=October 20, 2016 | author=Vercellotti, Timothy}} In contrast, several other studies have failed to demonstrate significant turnout reductions.{{Cite journal|title=The Empirical Effects of Voter-ID Laws: Present or Absent?|url=http://journals.cambridge.org/article_S1049096509090301 |journal=PS: Political Science & Politics|date=January 1, 2009|issn= 1537-5935|pages=121–26|volume= 42|issue= 01|doi= 10.1017/S1049096509090301|first=Jason D.|last=Mycoff|first2=Michael W.|last2=Wagner|first3=David C.|last3=Wilson}} A 2010 study found that 1.2% of registered voters in three states with voter ID laws (Indiana, Maryland, and Mississippi) lacked an ID that complied with the law.{{cite journal|last1=Pastor|first1=R. A.|last2=Santos|first2=R.|last3=Prevost|first3=A.|last4=Stoilov|first4=V.|title=Voting and ID Requirements: A Survey of Registered Voters in Three States|journal=The American Review of Public Administration|date=September 16, 2009|volume=40|issue=4|pages=461–81|doi=10.1177/0275074009342892|url=http://arp.sagepub.com/content/40/4/461.abstract}} A 2011 study found that photo ID laws were correlated with a 1.6% decline in turnout, and non-photo ID laws were correlated with a 2.2% decline.{{cite web | url=https://journalistsresource.org/studies/politics/elections/id-at-the-polls-assessing-the-impact-of-recent-state-voter-id-laws-on-voter-turnout | title=ID at the polls: Assessing the impact of recent state voter ID laws on voter turnout | work=[[Journalist's Resource]] | date=September 28, 2011 | accessdate=May 27, 2017 | author=Olver, Christopher}} In a 2014 review by the [[Government Accountability Office]] of the academic literature, five studies out of ten found that voter ID laws had no significant effect on overall turnout, four studies found that voter ID laws decreased overall turnout, and one study found that the laws increased overall turnout.{{Cite web|url=http://www.gao.gov/products/GAO-14-634 |title=Elections: Issues Related to State Voter Identification Laws|date=February 27, 2015|website=gao.gov|accessdate=April 3, 2016}} A 2014 [[Rice University]] study reported that [[Texas]]'s voter ID law decreased turnout mainly among people who incorrectly thought they did not have the type of ID needed to comply with the law. The authors of this study also suggested that an education campaign aimed at clearly communicating what types of ID are acceptable in Texas would be beneficial.{{Cite journal|last=Bill|first=Hobby,|last2=P.|first2=Jones, Mark|last3=Jim|first3=Granato,|last4=Renée|first4=Cross,|last5=Cong|first5=Huang,|last6=David|first6=Llanos,|last7=Chris|first7=Mainka,|last8=Kwok-Wai|first8=Wan,|last9=Ching-Hsing|first9=Wang,|date=2015|title=The Texas Voter ID Law and the 2014 Election: A Study of Texas’s 23rd Congressional District|url=https://scholarship.rice.edu/handle/1911/92679|language=en}} A 2016 study argued that, although no clear-cut relationship exists between strict voter ID laws and voter turnout, the disenfranchising impact of voter ID laws may be hidden by Democratic voter mobilization. Strong negative reactions to voter ID laws among Democratic constituencies could, in theory, boost Democratic turnout enough to compensate for effects of the laws themselves.{{Cite journal|title=Why the Sky Didn't Fall: Mobilizing Anger in Reaction to Voter ID Laws|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/pops.12332/abstract |journal=Political Psychology|date=February 1, 2016|issn= 1467-9221|pages= |doi= 10.1111/pops.12332|language=en|first=Nicholas A.|last=Valentino|first2=Fabian G.|last2=Neuner}} A 2007 report found a small increase in Democratic turnout in places with new voter ID laws.{{Cite web|url=http://www.in.gov/sos/elections/files/EffectsPhotographicIdentificationVoter_-_Jeffrey_Milyo.pdf |title=The Effects of Photographic Identification on Voter Turnout in Indiana: A County-Level Analysis|date= |accessdate = |website=in.gov}} A 2017 study found that 474 people tried to vote in [[United States Senate election in Virginia, 2014|Virginia's 2014 Senate election]], but could not do so because they lacked the proper ID to comply with the state's voter ID law. The same study found that turnout was higher in parts of the state where registered voters were less likely to have a driver's license. The authors suggested that "This unexpected relationship might be explained by a targeted Department of Elections mailing, suggesting that the initial impact of voter ID laws may hinge on efforts to notify voters likely to be affected."{{cite journal|last1=Hopkins|first1=Daniel J.|last2=Meredith|first2=Marc|last3=Morse|first3=Michael|last4=Smith|first4=Sarah|last5=Yoder|first5=Jesse|title=Voting But for the Law: Evidence from Virginia on Photo Identification Requirements|journal=Journal of Empirical Legal Studies|date=March 2017|volume=14|issue=1|pages=79–128|doi=10.1111/jels.12142}} ====Disparate impact==== Charges of racial discrimination in voter ID laws are founded in the [[disparate impact]] doctrine of constitutional law, which claims that any action—intentional or unintentional—that statistically disadvantages a protected class constitutes discrimination. Disparate impact is most often discussed in the context of [[African Americans]]. The moral validity and constitutionality of this doctrine is hotly debated.{{cite journal|jstor=20775015|title=The Future of Disparate Impact|journal=Michigan Law Review|date=June 2010|author=Primus, Richard}} This is relevant to voter ID laws because of accusations that these laws disproportionately reduce turnout among minority voters.{{cite web | url=https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2017/02/how-voter-id-laws-discriminate-study/517218/ | title=How Voter ID Laws Discriminate | work=The Atlantic | date=February 18, 2017 | accessdate=May 28, 2017 | author=Newkirk, Vann}} According to an assessment of the existing research on voter ID laws by University of Pennsylvania political scientist Dan Hopkins, the research indicates that voter ID laws do disproportionately disenfranchise minority voters. Research also shows that racial minorities are less likely to possess IDs.{{Cite journal|last=Barreto|first=Matt A.|last2=Nuño|first2=Stephen|last3=Sanchez|first3=Gabriel R.|last4=Walker|first4=Hannah L.|date=November 9, 2018|title=The Racial Implications of Voter Identification Laws in America|url=https://journals.sagepub.com/action/captchaChallenge?redirectUri=%2Fdoi%2F10.1177%2F1532673X18810012|journal=American Politics Research|language=en|pages=1532673X1881001|doi=10.1177/1532673x18810012|issn=1532-673X}} Federal appeals courts have struck down strict voter-ID laws in Texas and North Carolina, citing intent by the legislatures to discriminate against minority voters.{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/public-safety/appeals-court-strikes-down-north-carolinas-voter-id-law/2016/07/29/810b5844-4f72-11e6-aa14-e0c1087f7583_story.html|title=Appeals court strikes down North Carolina's voter-ID law|website=Washington Post|access-date=July 29, 2016}} The appeals court noted that the North Carolina Legislature "requested data on the use, by race, of a number of voting practices"—then, data in hand, "enacted legislation that restricted voting and registration in five different ways, all of which disproportionately affected African Americans."{{Cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2016/07/29/487935700/u-s-appeals-court-strikes-down-north-carolinas-voter-id-law|title=U.S. Appeals Court Strikes Down North Carolina's Voter ID Law|access-date=July 29, 2016}} The changes to the voting process "target African Americans with almost surgical precision," and "impose cures for problems that did not exist." A 2008 study found that the strictest voter ID laws reduced voter turnout relative to the most lax form of such laws (stating one's name). The same study reported that "the stricter voter identification requirements depress turnout to a greater extent for less educated and lower income populations, for both minorities and non-minorities."{{cite journal|last1=Alvarez|first1=R. Michael Michael|last2=Bailey|first2=Delia|last3=Katz|first3=Jonathan N.|title=The Effect of Voter Identification Laws on Turnout|journal=California Institute of Technology Social Science Working Paper|date=2008|doi=10.2139/ssrn.1084598}} A 2009 study found that 84% of white registered voters in Indiana had access to photo ID to comply with that state's ID law, as compared to 78% of black voters on the rolls there.{{cite journal|last1=Barreto|first1=Matt A.|last2=Nuño|first2=Stephen A.|last3=Sanchez|first3=Gabriel R.|title=The Disproportionate Impact of Voter-ID Requirements on the Electorate – New Evidence from Indiana|journal=PS: Political Science & Politics|date=January 8, 2009|volume=42|issue=01|pages=111|url=http://mattbarreto.com/papers/PS_VoterID.pdf|doi=10.1017/S1049096509090283}} A 2008 study found that African Americans, Hispanics, and the elderly were less likely to have a voter ID that complied with Georgia's voter ID law.{{cite journal|last1=Hood|first1=M.V.|last2=Bullock|first2=C. S.|title=Worth a Thousand Words?: An Analysis of Georgia's Voter Identification Statute|journal=American Politics Research|date=July 1, 2008|volume=36|issue=4|pages=555–79|doi=10.1177/1532673X08316608|url=http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/abs/10.1177/1532673X08316608}} A 2012 analysis by [[Nate Silver]] found that voter ID laws seem to decrease turnout by between 0.8% and 2.4%, depending on how strict they are, and tend to cause a shift towards the Republican candidate of between 0.4% and 1.2%. Silver found that the statistical reasoning was flawed in a number of studies which had found small effects but had described them as not statistically significant.{{Cite news|url=http://fivethirtyeight.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/07/15/measuring-the-effects-of-voter-identification-laws/|title=Measuring the Effects of Voter Identification Laws|last=Silver|first=Nate|newspaper=FiveThirtyEight|access-date=December 2, 2016}} In 2012, an investigation by [[Reuters]] found that voter ID laws in Georgia and Indiana had not led to lower turnout of minorities and concluded that concerns about this "are probably overstated".{{cite news|title=Insight: Scant evidence of voter suppression, fraud in states with ID laws|author=Colleen Jenkins|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/11/02/us-usa-campaign-voterid-idUSBRE8A10UJ20121102 |work=Reuters|date=November 2, 2012|accessdate=November 18, 2012}} In a 2014 review by the [[Government Accountability Office]] of the academic literature, three studies out of five found that voter ID laws reduced minority turnout whereas two studies found no significant impact. A 2014 study by the Government Accountability Office reported that voter ID laws in Kansas and Tennessee reduced turnout in these states by 1.9 and 2.2 percent, respectively, compared to four states that did not pass voter ID laws—Alabama, Arkansas, Delaware, and Maine. The study indicates that young people, black people, and newly registered voters were most likely to have their turnout reduced. But Tennessee officials suggested that the reduced turnout may have been due to a lack of compelling ballot measures in 2012, and Kansas officials dismissed the drop in black voters as a product of high [[variance|random variance]] in a small population. Tennessee officials questioned the reproducibility of this report, given its reliance on data from [[Catalist]], which they claimed was a [[Modern liberalism in the United States|progressive]] political group.{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2014/10/09/gao-voter-id-laws-in-kansas-and-tennessee-dropped-2012-turnout-by-over-100000-votes/ |title=Voter ID laws in Kansas and Tennessee dropped 2012 turnout by over 100,000 votes|work=Washington Post|date=October 9, 2014|accessdate=February 7, 2016|author=Bump, Philip}} A 2014 study from the [[University of Iowa]] found no evidence that strict voter ID laws reduce minority turnout.{{Cite journal|title=The Politics of Race and Voter ID Laws in the States The Return of Jim Crow?|url= http://prq.sagepub.com/content/67/3/666 |journal=Political Research Quarterly|date=September 1, 2014|issn= 1065-9129|pages=666–79|volume= 67|issue= 3|doi= 10.1177/1065912913514854|language=en|first=Rene R.|last=Rocha|first2=Tetsuya|last2=Matsubayashi}} A 2012 study found that, although the Georgia voter ID laws lowered overall turnout by 0.4%, there was no racial or ethnic component to the suppression effect. Disparate impact may also be reflected in access to information about voter ID laws. A 2015 experimental study found that election officials queried about voter ID laws were more likely to respond to emails from a non-Latino Anglo or European name (70.5% response rate) than a Latino name (64.8% response rate), though response accuracy was similar across those groups.{{Cite journal|title=What Do I Need to Vote? Bureaucratic Discretion and Discrimination by Local Election Officials|url=http://journals.cambridge.org/article_S0003055414000562 |journal=American Political Science Review|date=February 1, 2015|issn= 1537-5943|pages=129–42|volume= 109|issue= 01|doi= 10.1017/S0003055414000562|first=Ariel R.|last=White|first2=Noah L.|last2=Nathan|first3=Julie K.|last3=Faller}} Studies have also analyzed racial differences in ID requests rates. A 2012 study in the city of [[Boston]] found strong evidence that non-white voters were more likely to be asked for ID during the 2008 election. According to exit polls, 23% of whites, 33% of Asians, 33% of blacks, and 38% of Hispanics were asked for ID, though this effect is partially attributed to black and Hispanics preferring non-peak voting hours when election officials inspected a greater portion of IDs. Precinct differences confound the data, as black and Hispanic voters tended to vote at black and Hispanic-majority precincts.{{Cite journal|title=Can Voter ID Laws Be Administered in a Race-Neutral Manner? Evidence from the City of Boston in 2008|ssrn=1625041 |publisher=Social Science Research Network|date=June 14, 2010|location=Rochester, NY|first=Rachael V.|last=Cobb|last2=Greiner|first3=D.|last3=James|first4=Kevin M.|last4=Quinn}} A 2010 study of the 2006 midterm election in New Mexico found that election officials asked Hispanics for ID more often than they did early voters, women, and non-Hispanics.{{Cite journal|title=A new barrier to participation: Heterogeneous application of voter identification policies|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0261379409000912 |journal=Electoral Studies|date=March 1, 2010|pages=66–73|volume= 29|issue= 1|doi= 10.1016/j.electstud.2009.08.001|first=Lonna Rae|last=Atkeson|first2=Lisa Ann|last2=Bryant|first3=Thad E.|last3=Hall|first4=Kyle|last4=Saunders|first5=Michael|last5=Alvarez}} A 2009 study of the 2006 midterm elections nationwide found that 47% of white voters reported being asked to show photo identification at the polls, compared with 54% of Hispanics and 55% of African Americans."{{Cite journal|title=Effects of Identification Requirements on Voting: Evidence from the Experiences of Voters on Election Day|url=http://journals.cambridge.org/article_S1049096509090313 |journal=PS: Political Science & Politics|date=January 1, 2009|issn= 1537-5935|pages=127–130|volume= 42|issue= 01|doi= 10.1017/S1049096509090313|first=Stephen|last=Ansolabehere}} Very few people were denied the chance to vote as a result of voter identification requests. A 2015 study found that turnout among blacks in Georgia was generally higher since the state began enforcing its strict voter ID law.{{cite journal|last1=Gillespie|first1=June Andra|title=Voter Identification and Black Voter Turnout An Examination of Black Voter Turnout Patterns in Georgia, 2000–2014|journal=Phylon|volume=52|issue=2|pages=43–67|jstor=43681953 }} A 2017 study in the ''Journal of Politics'' "shows that strict identification laws have a differentially negative impact on the turnout of racial and ethnic minorities in primaries and general elections. We also find that voter ID laws skew democracy toward those on the political right."{{Cite journal|last=Hajnal|first=Zoltan|last2=Lajevardi|first2=Nazita|last3=Nielson|first3=Lindsay|date=January 5, 2017|title=Voter Identification Laws and the Suppression of Minority Votes|url=http://www.journals.uchicago.edu/doi/abs/10.1086/688343|journal=The Journal of Politics|pages=|doi=10.1086/688343|issn=0022-3816}} The results of this study were challenged in a paper by Stanford political scientist Justin Grimmer and four other political scientists.{{Cite journal|last=Grimmer|first=Justin|last2=Hersh|first2=Eitan|last3=Meredith|first3=Marc|last4=Mummolo|first4=Jonathan|last5=Nall|first5=Clayton|date=April 18, 2018|title=Obstacles to Estimating Voter ID Laws' Effect on Turnout|url=https://www.journals.uchicago.edu/doi/abs/10.1086/696618|journal=The Journal of Politics|pages=000–000|doi=10.1086/696618|issn=0022-3816}} The paper says that the findings in the aforementioned study "a product of data inaccuracies, the presented evidence does not support the stated conclusion, and alternative model specifications produce highly variable results. When errors are corrected, one can recover positive, negative, or null estimates of the effect of voter ID laws on turnout, precluding firm conclusions." In a response, the authors of the original study dismissed the aforementioned criticisms, and stood by the findings of the original article.{{Cite journal|last=Hajnal|first=Zoltan|last2=Kuk|first2=John|last3=Lajevardi|first3=Nazita|date=April 18, 2018|title=We All Agree: Strict Voter ID Laws Disproportionately Burden Minorities|url=https://www.journals.uchicago.edu/doi/abs/10.1086/696617|journal=The Journal of Politics|pages=000–000|doi=10.1086/696617|issn=0022-3816}} Columbia University statistician and political scientist Andrew Gelman said that the response by the authors of the original study "did not seem convincing" and that the finding of racial discrepancies in the original study does not stand.{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/monkey-cage/wp/2018/06/11/a-new-controversy-erupts-over-whether-voter-identification-laws-suppress-minority-turnout/|title=Analysis {{!}} A new controversy erupts over whether voter identification laws suppress minority turnout|last=Gelman|first=Andrew|date=June 11, 2018|work=Washington Post|access-date=June 11, 2018|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}} A 2017 report by Civis Analytics for the liberal super PAC Priorities USA purported to show that Hillary Clinton lost Wisconsin the 2016 presidential election due to voter suppression brought on by Wisconsin's strict voter ID laws.{{Cite news|url=http://www.politifact.com/wisconsin/statements/2017/may/24/tammy-baldwin/photo-id-law-caused-200000-drop-wisconsin-voter-tu/|title=Wisconsin photo ID law cut turnout by 200,000 voters?|work=@politifact|access-date=December 20, 2017|language=en}} Political scientists expressed serious skepticism of the report's methodology; Yale University political scientist Eitan Hersh said the report "does not meet acceptable evidence standards." A 2017 paper by University of Wisconsin-Madison political scientists Kenneth Mayer and Michael DeCrescenzo also purported to show that voter suppression swayed Wisconsin from Clinton; this paper was also rebutted by other political scientists on the basis of poor methodology.{{Cite news|url=https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/politics-moves-fast-peer-review-moves-slow-whats-a-political-scientist-to-do/|title=Politics Moves Fast. Peer Review Moves Slow. What's A Political Scientist To Do?|last=Koerth-Baker|first=Maggie|date=December 19, 2017|work=FiveThirtyEight|access-date=December 20, 2017|language=en-US}} ===International comparisons=== Many nations require some form of voter identification at the polling place, but specific details of the requirement vary widely. In [[Spain]], [[Greece]], [[France]], [[Belgium]], and [[Italy]], a government-issued photo ID is required to cast a ballot. However, all citizens in these nations are automatically provided with a photo ID upon reaching adulthood. [[Mexico]] has a similar system, with all registered voters receiving a photo ID upon completing the registration process.{{cite journal|last1=Schaffer|first1=Frederic Charles|last2=Wang|first2=Tova Andrea|title=Is Everyone Else Doing It? Indiana's Voter Identification Law in International Perspective|work=Harvard Law and Policy Review|date=2009 |url=http://harvardlpr.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/05/3.2_8_Schaffer.pdf |accessdate=February 15, 2016}} Several Western democracies do not require identification for voting, such as Denmark, Australia, New Zealand, and the United Kingdom. In [[Ireland]], [[Sweden]], and [[Switzerland]], poll workers reserve the right to request identification but are not required to do so. In [[Canada]], identification is required, but voters can provide any two forms of ID from a list of 45 possibilities. Canada's system is more stringent than the 17 U.S. states that do not require ID but less stringent than the 22 U.S. states with strict requirements. The strict Indiana ID system, for instance, accepts only five forms of ID: an Indiana driver's license, an Indiana ID card, a military ID, a [[United States passport|US passport]], or a [[student ID card]] from an in-state college or university. Conversely, some countries, like [[Elections in Australia|Australia]], require no form of identification at any election.{{cite web|url=http://www.aec.gov.au/Voting/polling.htm|title=Voting at a polling place|first=corporateName=Australian Electoral Commission; address=50 Marcus Clarke Street, Canberra ACT 2600; contact=13 23|last=26|website=Australian Electoral Commission|accessdate=August 14, 2018}} This position is similar to the situation in New York and California. Several developing nations have instituted voter ID laws. Many Arab nations require voters to leave a fingerprint upon casting a ballot, allowing quick detection of fraud.{{cite web|url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2012/11/06/foreign-election-officials-amazed-by-trust-based-u-s-voting-system-2/ |title=Foreign election officials amazed by trust-based U.S. voting system|work=Foreign Policy|date=November 2012|accessdate=February 15, 2016}} In 2012, the head of [[Libya|Libya's]] national election commission expressed surprise that the American system "depends so much on trust and the good faith of election officials and voters alike". Likewise, [[India]] requires one of fifteen forms of identification to vote. [[The Gambia]] gives each voter a single marble to cast, ensuring that no one can vote multiple times. ===Public opinion=== Public opinion polls have shown support for voter ID laws among voters in the United States. A 2011 [[Rasmussen poll]] found that 75% of likely voters "believe voters should be required to show photo identification, such as a driver's license, before being allowed to vote."{{cite news|last=Roff|first=Peter|url=https://www.usnews.com/opinion/blogs/peter-roff/2011/06/10/poll-democrats-and-republicans-support-a-voter-id-check-law |title=Poll: Democrats and Republicans Support a Voter ID-Check Law|work=U.S. News & World Report|date=June 10, 2011|accessdate=May 16, 2012}} A Pew poll showed that 95% of Republicans, 83% of independent voters, and 61% of [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrats]] favor requirements that voters should show photo IDs to vote.{{cite news|url=http://www.people-press.org/2012/10/11/broad-support-for-photo-id-voting-requirements/ |title=Broad Support for Photo ID Voting Requirements|work=Pew Center|date=October 11, 2012|accessdate=February 18, 2016}} A 2012 [[Fox News]] poll produced similar results, revealing that 87% of Republicans, 74% of independent voters, and 52% of Democrats supported new voter ID laws.{{cite news|last=Blanton|first=Dana|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2012/04/18/fox-news-poll-most-think-voter-id-laws-are-necessary/ |title=Fox News Poll: Most think voter ID laws are necessary|work=Fox News|date=April 18, 2012|accessdate=May 16, 2012}} Although all major political demographics support voter ID laws, a 2013 study showed significant divergence in opinion between conservative-affiliated demographics, which are staunch supporters, and liberal-affiliated demographics, which are less supportive. The study also showed that support depends on survey framing: when [[Leading question|questions biased]] against voter ID laws are asked, support drops 15% compared to when questions favorable to voter ID laws are asked. A 2016 study showed that emphasizing the adverse effects of voter ID laws on eligible voters decreased popular support for such laws.{{cite journal|last1=Wilson|first1=David C.|last2=Brewer|first2=Paul R.|title=Do Frames Emphasizing Harm to Age and Racial-Ethnic Groups Reduce Support for Voter ID Laws?|journal=Social Science Quarterly|date=January 2016|pages= |doi=10.1111/ssqu.12234}} Another 2016 study found that white people with high levels of implicit [[racism]], but not explicit racism, were more supportive of voter ID laws when they were exposed to a fear-eliciting condition.{{cite journal|last1=Banks|first1=Antoine J.|last2=Hicks|first2=Heather M.|title=Fear and Implicit Racism: Whites' Support for Voter ID laws|journal=Political Psychology|date=August 2015|pages= |doi=10.1111/pops.12292}} A 2016 study found that partisan affiliation is a major determinant of support for voter ID laws and that Republicans are especially likely to be concerned about voter fraud.{{cite journal|last1=Atkeson|first1=Lonna Rae|last2=Alvarez|first2=R. Michael|last3=Hall|first3=Thad E.|last4=Sinclair|first4=J. Andrew|title=Balancing Fraud Prevention and Electoral Participation: Attitudes Toward Voter Identification|journal=Social Science Quarterly|date=December 2014|volume=95|issue=5|pages=1381–98|doi=10.1111/ssqu.12110}} Research shows that Individuals who hold anti-immigrant views are most likely to believe that voter fraud is rampant.{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/monkey-cage/wp/2017/02/01/who-believes-in-voter-fraud-americans-who-are-hostile-to-immigrants/|title=Who believes in voter fraud? Americans who are hostile to immigrants|website=Washington Post|access-date=February 1, 2017}} ===Politicization of voter ID issues=== In 2014, a study released by the [[Congressional Research Service]] concluded that, in the absence of systematic risk analyses, it is difficult to determine what points in the election process—[[voter registration]], voting systems, [[polling place]] location and hours, pollworker training, voter identification, vote tabulation, or other steps—involve the greatest potential risks to election integrity and therefore warrant the greatest attention.Coleman, K.J. et al. (November 3, 2014) [http://fas.org/sgp/crs/misc/R42806.pdf Voter Identification Requirements: Background and Legal Issues] Washington, D.C. Another 2014 study argued that careful [[voter roll]] maintenance is probably a more effective method for preventing voter fraud than voter ID laws. A 2015 study found that local coverage of voter fraud during the 2012 elections was greatest in presidential [[swing state]]s and states that passed strict vote ID laws prior to the 2012 election. There was no evidence that the reporting was related to the actual rate of voter fraud in each state. Based on this data, the authors concluded that "parties and campaigns sought to place voter fraud on the political agenda in strategically important states to motivate their voting base ahead of the election".{{Cite journal|title=News attention to voter fraud in the 2008 and 2012 US elections|url=http://rap.sagepub.com/content/2/2/2053168015587156 |journal=Research & Politics|date=April 1, 2015|issn= 2053-1680|volume= 2|issue= 2|doi= 10.1177/2053168015587156|first=Brian J.|last=Fogarty|first2=Jessica|last2=Curtis|first3=Patricia Frances|last3=Gouzien|first4=David C.|last4=Kimball|first5=Eric C.|last5=Vorst}} Another 2015 study found a similar correlation between the enactment of voter ID laws and a state's electoral competitiveness, suggesting [[electioneering]] motives.{{Cite journal|title=A Principle or a Strategy? Voter Identification Laws and Partisan Competition in the American States|url=http://prq.sagepub.com/content/68/1/18 |journal=Political Research Quarterly|date=March 1, 2015|issn= 1065-9129|pages=18–33|volume= 68|issue= 1|doi= 10.1177/1065912914554039|language=en|first=William D.|last=Hicks|first2=Seth C.|last2=McKee|first3=Mitchell D.|last3=Sellers|first4=Daniel A.|last4=Smith}} A 2016 study found polarization over voter ID laws was less stark in state legislatures where electoral competition was not intense.{{Cite journal|last=Hicks|first=William D.|last2=McKee|first2=Seth C.|last3=Smith|first3=Daniel A.|date=February 21, 2016|title=The Determinants of State Legislator Support for Restrictive Voter ID Laws|url=http://spa.sagepub.com/content/early/2016/02/19/1532440016630752 |journal=State Politics & Policy Quarterly|language=en|pages=|doi=10.1177/1532440016630752|issn=1532-4400}} The same 2016 study found a notable relationship between the racial composition of a member's district, region, and electoral competition, and the likelihood that a state lawmaker supported a voter ID bill. The study found that "Democratic lawmakers representing substantial black district populations are more ''opposed'' to restrictive voter ID laws, whereas Republican legislators with substantial black district populations are more ''supportive''." Southern lawmakers (particularly Democrats) were more opposed to restrictive voter ID legislation. Black legislators in the [[Southern USA|South]] were the least supportive of restrictive voter ID bills. A 2018 experimental study in ''[[Legislative Studies Quarterly]]'', which sent messages from Latino and white constituents to lawmakers, found that lawmakers who supported voter ID laws were less likely to respond to messages sent by Latino constituents.{{Cite journal|last=Mendez|first=Matthew S.|last2=Grose|first2=Christian R.|date=June 12, 2018|title=Doubling Down: Inequality in Responsiveness and the Policy Preferences of Elected Officials|url=https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1111/lsq.12204|journal=Legislative Studies Quarterly|language=en|doi=10.1111/lsq.12204|issn=0362-9805}} A 2017 study in ''American Politics Research'' found that the adoption of voter ID laws is most likely when control of the governor's office and state legislature switches to Republicans, and when the size of black and Latino populations in the state increases.{{Cite journal|last=Biggers|first=Daniel R.|last2=Hanmer|first2=Michael J.|date=January 16, 2017|title=Understanding the Adoption of Voter Identification Laws in the American States|url=http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/full/10.1177/1532673X16687266|journal=American Politics Research|language=en|doi=10.1177/1532673x16687266}} Another 2017 study found that the different advertising strategies used to advertise [[Kansas]]' voter ID laws by different county clerks influenced the effect of these laws on turnout.{{cite journal|last1=Bright|first1=Chelsie L. M.|last2=Lynch|first2=Michael S.|title=Kansas Voter ID Laws|journal=Political Research Quarterly|date=February 2017|volume=70|issue=2|pages=340–347|doi=10.1177/1065912917691638|url=http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/full/10.1177/1065912917691638}} Several states controlled by Democrats maintain voter ID laws. For instance, [[Hawaii]] has required a state-issued photo ID for decades. In 2011, the [[Rhode Island]] legislature enacted a photo ID requirement, which was signed by governor [[Lincoln Chafee]], making Rhode Island the most recent state controlled by Democrats to pass such legislation.{{cite news|url=http://www.governing.com/blogs/politics/rhode-island-voter-ID-law-game-changer.html|title=Rhode Island's Voter ID Law: Oddity or Game-Changer|date=July 28, 2011|author=Louis Jacobson|website=governing.com|accessdate=January 18, 2016}} However, both Hawaii and Rhode Island are "non-strict photo ID states", meaning that, in some circumstances, an [[affidavit]] or other legal measure can satisfy the ID requirement. A 2018 study by the [[Williams Institute]] found that 137,000 [[transgender]] people who have transitioned will be eligible to vote in the [[2018 US election]] in states with strict voter ID laws. An estimated 57% of them may not have identification or documentation that accurately reflects their gender. Eight states currently have strict voter ID laws that require voters to provide a government-issued photo ID in order to vote at the polls. In these states, election officials and poll workers decide whether a voter's identification accurately identifies the voter and matches the information listed in the voter registration rolls.{{cite web |title= |last1=Herman |first1=Jody L. |last2=Brown |first2=Taylor N.T. |url=https://williamsinstitute.law.ucla.edu/research/voter-id-laws-2018/ |date=August 2018 |website=Williams Institute |publisher=UCLA School of Law |accessdate=August 25, 2018 |quote= }} ==Laws by state== {| class = "sortable wikitable" |- !
